en.value: Describing food and whether you liked it - Questions in past tenses - Describing an experience at a restaurant
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
There are many ways to say that food is "delicious". You may hear the words "tasty" and "yummy". All of them have similar meanings!
Select the correct sentence to say you liked your food.
It was alright, but quite bland.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
I like to add chilli and make my food [k]spicy[/k]!
This describes food that doesn't taste of much.
The chicken was a bit dry.
It was great, but very greasy.

We can use the words "light" and "heavy" not only to describe the weight of something, but also to talk about types of meals. Something light may be a salad or fruit. Something heavy may be a roast, or pasta.
Let’s just have a light lunch, because we’re having a big dinner tonight.
I don’t want anything too heavy. I’m not that hungry.
Select what type of food you'd eat if you didn't want something heavy.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
The chicken at the new restaurant is very [k]dry[/k].
We can use this word when something's very oily.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Michael, do you want to go to the new restaurant down the road for lunch?
Yes, I hear the food is [k]delicious[/k]!
I hear they have some nice [k]greasy[/k] burgers!
Oh good! I don't fancy that today, but I'm sure they have something [k]light[/k].
Definitely! I just need something tasty this time... Catherine and I went for lunch together last week and had the worst meal, everything was [k]bland[/k] and [k]dry[/k].
That's ok, we made up by having some [k]sweet[/k] and [k]salty[/k] popcorn at the office.
Why does Michael want to go to the restaurant?
Fill in the gap using the hint.
The food at this restaurant is [k]delicious|yummy|tasty[/k].
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Why was the food they ate bad?
My sister can't cook, her food is [k]bland[/k] and dry.
The popcorn they shared had two flavours.
I prefer [k]salty[/k] food over sweet food.

People who are interested in different languages and cultures often enjoy trying new food. What's a popular dish in your country or region? How does it taste? Start a conversation with a member of the busuu community today!
I'm from ... / A popular dish here is ... / It tastes ...
Grammar: Questions in the past tenses

Now that we know how to use a few past tenses in English, let’s practise forming questions. Here we’ll get comfortable with asking questions about things that happened in the past. Below you'll find a quick reminder of the question words we might use.
Who - to ask about a person / people
What - to ask about a thing / specific information
How - to ask about manner, condition or quality
Select the question words we use to ask about place and time.
Here's a quick reminder on how to ask questions in the past simple and past continuous.
Question word (optional) + "was / were" + person / thing + -ing form of the verb ...?
The events in the story you hear are happening now.
The events in the story happened in the past.
Select the words in the correct order.

You've probably come across the question word "how" when asking how somebody is feeling ("How are you?"), about somebody's age ("How old are you?") or about the price of something ("How much is it?"). Have a look at the examples below to see some questions we can ask using "how" + different adjectives and adverbs.
How ...? - to ask what an event or experience was like
How much ...? - to ask about the price or amount of something
Select the words we use to ask about the price or amount of something.
How old? [h]How[/h] [h]much[/h]? How often? How far? How long?
Select the most likely question for the response you hear.
How many friends did they invite to the party?
How much did they pay for the party?
How often did they invite friends around?
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Match the beginning and the end of the sentences.
[k]When did you do the washing[/k] last time?
Jesse's friend showed up very late. He'd like to know the reason.
[k]Why were you|Why are you[/k] so late, Miles?
Type the most likely question for this response.
[k]Where did you go|Where did we go[/k] on holiday?

The question word “who” sometimes behaves differently from the others. That’s because it can play different roles in a sentence. Sometimes, it replaces the person performing the action. In these cases, “who” goes before the verb and the rest of the question has the same structure as a positive sentence.
Select the question which is structured correctly.
[k]What[/k] [k]did[/k] you order as the main course?
Type a question for the response "They went swimming." using one of the words below.
Mira is asking about the price of your meal yesterday. Type the missing words.
Now let's practise asking questions in the present perfect. To form a question in this tense, we also need to change the word order. Have a look at the structure below and some examples.
Statement: She has been away for the whole week.
Question: How long has she been away for?
We use the present perfect tense to talk about some recent events.
Type the question for the response "Sandra has just arrived."
[k]What have you cooked[/k] for us today, Maggy?
Your friend has been away on holiday. Ask her where she went, using the present perfect.
I haven't seen you for ages. [k]Where have you been[/k]?
To recap, have another look at how to form questions in different past tenses:
At this level in the course we'd like to challenge your listening comprehension skills. This will help you in real-life situations you might encounter.
Listen to the audio. Which statement is true?
[k]I've[/k] booked a table for four, under the name "Edwards".
Listen to the audio. Which of these verbs can you hear in the present perfect?
Complete the sentence to form the present perfect.
Listen to the audio. What is Harriet asking?
if there are any vegetarian dishes on the menu
how many vegetarian dishes there are on the menu
why there aren't any vegetarian options on the menu
Complete the sentence with the past participle of "to be".
My friends have [k]been[/k] here before, but it's my first time.
Here's the dialogue we've just heard again.

Harriet: I've booked a table for four, under the name "Edwards". Waiter: Sure, let me check. Did you book online? Harriet: I think I called. Waiter: Ah, I've found you. "Edwards", table for four. Follow me, please! Have you eaten here before? Harriet: My friends have been here before, but it's my first time. Waiter: Okay, so, here's our menu. Our specials are on the first page, followed by the starters and mains. The drinks are at the back. I can bring you a dessert menu later, if you want dessert. Please let me know if you have any questions! Harriet: Perfect, thank you! Do you have any vegetarian options? Waiter: Yes! You can find vegetarian, vegan and dairy-free options clearly labelled on the menu.
Listen to the audio and select the sentence with the closest meaning.
I think the edamame sounds good. It's not too [k]heavy[/k].
The waiter brings the menu. Which of these items CANNOT be found on it?
Oh yeah, you're right! I [k]didn't read[/k] the description properly, thank you!
Listen to the audio. Which of these verbs can you hear in the past simple?
Rewrite this sentence in the past simple.
[k]The chicken was dry and the sauce wasn't spicy enough|The chicken was dry and the sauce was not spicy enough[/k].
The chicken is dry and the sauce isn't spicy enough.
Select the correct definition of the word you hear.

Harriet: Shall we order some starters to share? Alex: Sure! I think the edamame sounds good. It’s not too heavy. Harriet: Yummy! Let's get that and some kimchi? Alex: Perfect! As a main, I feel like having something light... Maybe I'll try the noodles with a sweet and sour dressing. Harriet: Look, that dish contains peanuts. You're allergic to nuts, right? Alex: Oh yeah, you're right! I didn't read the description properly, thank you! I'll get the soup instead. Harriet: How was the chicken curry you ate here last time? Alex: It was delicious except for the meat. The chicken was a bit dry and the sauce wasn't spicy enough for me. Harriet: OK, so it wasn't too greasy? Alex: No, it wasn't at all! You're vegan though, right? Harriet: Yes! So I'll have the curry with tofu instead of chicken. Let's order, I'm hungry!
Listen to the audio. Which statement is true?
She left some food on her plate.
Rewrite this sentence to make it negative.
[k]I didn't finish my meal|I did not finish my meal[/k].
Select the words that mean "to top up".
Whenever he topped up our drinks he [k]was[/k] [k]asking[/k] if we were enjoying ourselves.

Harriet: How was everything? Alex: The soup was absolutely delicious! Full of flavour, not bland at all! I really enjoyed it. How was the curry? Harriet: It was a bit salty but not too spicy, and the tofu was really yummy. I didn't finish it because the portion was so big. Alex: I also thought the service here was quite good. Is the service charge included in the bill or do we need to tip? Harriet: I'm not sure actually, but I was very happy with our waiter. Whenever he topped up our drinks he was asking if we were enjoying ourselves. Alex: Yeah, he was very attentive.
